docs.lead_paragraph: Some mornings after everyone else has left for work, Shane Daniels slips behind the wheel of his car and dreams about being on his own again, free to drive himself anywhere he wants to go. But Mr. Daniels has not been able to drive or do a lot of other things on his own since the early morning hours of May 26, when he became a victim of a racially charged attack in the parking lot of a Westhampton Beach nightclub.

headline.main: Beating Victim Longs for 'Control of My Life'

docs.abstract: Interview with Shane Daniels, victim of racially charged May beating outside Westhampton Beach nightclub, on his continuing recovery; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The surprise announcement this week by Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield that it would convert to a for-profit health insurer seemed to mark the end of its historic role as a nonprofit protector of New York's sickest and poorest individuals -- the people other insurers try to shun. In truth, that role ended earlier this year when a new state law kicked in that requires every managed care plan, not just Empire's, to enroll chronically ill applicants. Another law, passed this year, ends Empire's discounts for hospital fees. Stripped of its special mission and subsidies, Empire's management had to figure out how it would marshal enough resources to compete against well-financed commercial insurers. Management decided that Empire, like many nonprofit insurers across the country, would need to sell shares to profit-seeking investors.
docs.abstract: Editorial supports Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield's decision to convert to for-profit health insurer; contends that Empire should become attractive option for consumers in competitive field of managed care; holds that Empire's proposal would create richly endowed foundation whose mission would be to help provide health coverage to poor (M)

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: EMPIRE BLUE CROSS AND BLUE SHIELD

docs.lead_paragraph: With Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield turning itself into a for-profit company, the people who stand to benefit most, should the conversion succeed, would be the company's executives -- who could get higher pay -- and the eventual stockholders, who would see their holdings grow if the company thrives. But in the short run, the newly reconstituted company would most benefit investment bankers and the lawyers and public relations advisers whom companies typically hire to help with such deals.

headline.main: Blue Cross Change Seen As Windfall for Advisers

docs.lead_paragraph: Conseco Inc., a financial services company, is buying the insurer Transport Holdings Inc. for $311 million. It is the sixth acquisition Conseco has announced this year. Transport Holdings provides cancer insurance and other supplemental health insurance products. Conseco, based in suburban Indianapolis, said yesterday that it would pay $70 a share, or about $228 million, to buy Transport Holdings' 3.2 million common shares and other securities. Conseco will also spend $83 million to retire Transport Holdings' bank debt and preferred stock. Transport Holdings' shares soared 35 percent, gaining $18.375, to $70.125, on the Nasdaq stock market. Conseco's shares gained $2.625, to $49.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline.main: CONSECO MAKES ITS SIXTH ACQUISITION OF YEAR

docs.abstract: Conseco Inc is buying Transport Holdings Inc for $311 million, including $83 million to retire Transport Holdings' bank debt and preferred stock (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: New Jerseyans were better off financially than most other Americans last year, but a comparatively high percentage were not protecting themselves from the potential costs of catastrophic illness, the Census Bureau reported yesterday. The surveys showed that New Jersey's median income last year was $43,924, up slightly from 1994 and second only to Alaska's. New Jersey had a poverty rate of 7.8 percent last year, the nation's third-lowest after Alaska and New Hampshire. The state's poverty rate has fallen from 9.2 percent in 1994 and 10.9 percent in 1993.
docs.abstract: Census Bureau reports that New Jersey's median income last year was $43,924, up slightly from 1994 and second only to Alaska; reports that state's poverty rate was 7.8%, nation's third-lowest after Alaska and New Hampshire; reports that 14.2% of state's residents were not covered by health insurance, up from 13% in 1994; 26 states ranked higher than New Jersey in percentage of residents with health coverage (S) (New Jersey Daily Briefing)

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton began today by signing a bill to insure 48-hour hospital stays for mothers and newborns, and ended it by raising $3 million to help Democratic Senate campaigns around the country. In between, he went to Capitol Hill for a love-fest pep talk with Democratic members of Congress with whom he has not always seen eye-to-eye. It was yet another in the steady string of untroubled days that have become commonplace for a President who once seemed to attract trouble routinely.

headline.main: Clinton Buoys His Party in Capitol Hill Visit

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton buoys fellow Democrats with visit to Capitol Hill and campaign pep talk; starts day by signing bill to insure 48-hour hospital stays for mothers and newborns; photo; ends day at dinner that raises $3 million for Democratic Senate candidates (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: NEW YORK Workfare Conditions Protested Angry about conditions on their jobs, some welfare recipients required to work for their benefits say they should receive many protections available to other workers. While not objecting to work itself, they complain that they are occupying a new basement tier in the labor force, one that lacks regulations on hours, wages and safety that other workers take for granted. $(Page B1.$) Treasure or Tragedy? Beneath Liberty Street in lower Manhattan, 9,000 tons of gold are stored in the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. They are part of an unfinished tale, with roots in Nazi Germany and mass murder. The core questions: Is the gold a remnant of booty that the Nazis looted during World War II, and does it include melted-down teeth and jewelry of Jews who died in the Holocaust? NYC by Clyde Haberman. $(B1.$) TriBeCa Egg Man Hangs On Well before a city planner in the 1970's christened the area TriBeCa, the blocks just north of Chambers Street and east of Greenwich Street were the egg, butter and cheese center of New York. Now, the section consists of Steven Wils, the owner of a family wholesaling business and the last butter-and-egg man in TriBeCa. With 16 trucks chugging in and out of Duane Street, he hardly does things in the way of his grandfather and father. $(B1.$) Yankees' Fans Savor Victory After 15 years of the sobriety of finishing a baseball season without their team in first place, Yankee fans were able to drink the sugary taste of success as their heroes became the champions of the American League Eastern Division. Now they must await the playoff, which begins with home games on Tuesday and Wednesday. $(B3.$) Judge May Reopen Polls A judge who has been asked to order new primary elections because of ballot problems that kept voters away from the polls in Brooklyn said that in at least one race, he may instead reopen the polls for those voters who were turned away. $(B3.$) Controls Sought on Research Prompted by the case of a healthy 19-year-old college student who died of a heart attack after volunteering for a medical research project, state health officials assailed the researchers responsible for the study and called for stricter rules for such experiments. $(B4.$) Blue Cross Plan Questioned Many advocates and health care professionals questioned the new foundation that Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield said it would establish to help pay for the medical needs of the poor and uninsured as part of its move to become a for-profit insurance company. $(B6.$) Should the conversion of Blue Cross succeed, executives would benefit most. Until then, company advisers have the most to gain. $(B6.$) The prosecution wrapped up its homicide case against a Bronx police officer with testimony from the victim's father. $(B2.$) Two former police officers were sentenced for dealing drugs, illegally breaking into property and taking payoffs from narcotics dealers. $(B2.$) NEW JERSEY Plan to Limit Newborns' Stays The Whitman administration outlined a far-reaching plan to reduce the hospital stays for infants who are ready to leave the hospital but remain, sometimes months at a time, because their families are unwilling or unable to care for them. The plan includes expanding prenatal care programs and enlarging the pool of foster homes. $(B4.$) Casino Concessions Approved The New Jersey Assembly gave final legislative approval to the last of several concessions sought by Stephen A. Wynn before he would agree to proceed with a $2 billion casino and hotel project in the marina area of Atlantic City. No Democrats voted in favor of the bill, which they characterized as an unwarranted windfall for Mr. Wynn. $(B6.$) REGION 12 Years Later, a Reunion When the mother last laid eyes on her baby, he was 10 months old. Twelve years later, in the climax of a drama that could have been scripted for a made-for-TV movie, Federal authorities flew the mother from the Midwest to New York, where she was reunited with her son. The authorities say the boy was abducted by his father, who was arrested in the Bronx. $(B1.$) Fears on Crash Wreckage Technical experts investigating the crash of T.W.A. Flight 800 say they are growing increasingly worried that corrosion from salt water may have erased from metal wreckage the evidence investigators say they must find to show whether the plane was brought down by a bomb, a missile or mechanical failure. $(B4.$) A Sky Show Free for All People throughout the region gathered outdoors to watch a free, spectacular and rare occurrence: a total eclipse of the Moon (a harvest moon, at that), the last to be visible in North America until the year 2000. $(B6.$)

docs.lead_paragraph: Household income rose in 1995 for the first time in six years, the Census Bureau reported today, as the number of poor people in the United States dropped by more than 1.6 million, reaching historic lows for blacks and the elderly. The bureau said half the households in the country had incomes of at least $34,074, an increase of 2.7 percent over the previous year. The inflation-adjusted increase of $898 was the first rise in median household income since 1989, the year before the nation's last recession, and it was the largest increase in household earnings since 1986.

headline.main: U.S. CENSUS FINDS FIRST INCOME RISE IN PAST SIX YEARS

docs.abstract: Census Bureau reports household income rose in 1995 for first time in six years, and number of poor people dropped by more than 1.6 million, reaching historic lows for blacks and the elderly; half of American households had incomes of at least $34,074, up 2.7 percent from 1994, while percentage of people in poverty declined to 13.8, from 14.5 in 1994; 29.3 percent of blacks are shown below poverty line, while rate for people over 65 drops below that for working-age population; graphs; much of rise is in Midwest; Pres Clinton points to his economic policies, while Bob Dole says gains come from more people working in household; median household income is $40,243 in Connecticut, $33,028 in New York, $43,924 in New Jersey (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: For more than a year, the unique role that Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield has played in New York's health care system has been eroding steadily, so Wednesday's announcement that its executives wanted to turn it into a for-profit insurer served only as a final acknowledgment: the company was no longer the insurer of last resort for the state's most grievously ill. But company officials said yesterday that Blue Cross's policyholders would not see any difference in their coverage if the change is approved by the various regulatory bodies. Some 242,000 people who receive insurance to supplement their Federal Medicare coverage will remain insured if they so choose, the officials said.

headline.main: Questions Raised on Plan for Blue Cross

docs.abstract: Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield's announcement that it will seek to become for-profit insurer prompts health-care advocates to raise questions about new foundation Blue Cross will establish, with large endowment to help pay for medical needs of the very poor and uninsured in New York, as way to pay back the public subsidies it has received over the years (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: NEW YORK Blue Cross Seeks Profit Status Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield of New York, one of the country's largest nonprofit health care companies, said it would seek state approval to become a for-profit insurance company that would no longer be the health insurer of last resort. It said it would set up a charitable foundation to help New York residents who have no health insurance. $(Page A1.$) New Opposition to Superstores Mayor Giuliani's proposal to allow superstores to locate in New York City's manufacturing zones has been met with furious opposition. And with the plan nearing crucial votes, 15 City Council members urged the Mayor to drop the plan. $(B1.$) Prayer and Positive Thinking Prayers and requests for them radiate through the Norman Vincent Peale Center for Christian Living in Pawling, N.Y. Though Dr. Peale's ''Power of Positive Thinking'' focuses more on individual endeavor than on adherence to scripture, it is hard to imagine a place where the biblical directive to ''pray without ceasing'' is taken more literally. $(B1.$) Spreading the Word on Welfare Having received widespread attention for his outspoken positions in favor of immigration and against parts of the new Federal welfare law, Mayor Giuliani has recently found a new avocation: becoming what an aide calls the national spokesman for these issues. $(B1.$) City Hall Gets a Laugh Track The television set in the gym was tuned to the new ABC hit ''Spin City,'' in which Michael J. Fox plays a deputy mayor. But aside from the blue in the Blue Room, the City Hall in the series has little in common with the real one. Metro Matters by Joyce Purnick. $(B1.$) Welfare Rules Bring Confusion Under new orders to deny food stamps to innumerable legal immigrants who had previously qualified for them, workers are finding that translating law into reality is not easy. Throughout the New York region, there seemed more confusion than certainty about the cuts ordered by the new Federal law. $(B3.$) Union Reports Crowded Classes In another measure of the overcrowding in New York City public schools, the teachers' union reported that one of every six classes had more students than allowed under the union's contract. $(B3.$) Judge Faulted for Harassment The New York State Commission on Judicial Conduct recommended that Justice Lorraine S. Miller of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn be censured for sending dozens of anonymous, offensive mailings to newspapers and individuals about her former lover, Justice S. Barrett Hickman of State Supreme Court in Putnam Country, and his new wife. $(B3.$) Gas Leak Sought in Blast Investigators trying to determine the precise cause of an explosion that destroyed a Presbyterian church and two houses in Queens said they had found no leaks in gas lines outside the church building. But officials said they still believed that the blast was caused by a gas leak. $(B5.$) Opponents Share a Victory For 16 years, officials of Yonkers and the city's civil rights leaders have been locked in a nasty battle over the desegregation of the school system. On Tuesday, though, these onetime enemies were embracing like grizzled allies. Together, they celebrated a victory over an entity they have come to see as a common foe: the State of New York. News analysis. $(B6.$) Man Indicted in Embezzlement The former administrator of the Village of New Square in Rockland County was indicted on charges that he embezzled more than $750,000 from a housing complex and a nursing agency. $(B6.$) State Fights Woodland Sale The Nassau County Council of Boy Scouts wants to sell 147 acres of untouched woodland in a protected part of Long Island's pine barrens to a golf-course developer for $2 million, prompting a state agency to offer $1.3 million for the Scouts' development rights. $(B6.$) Board Not Told of Adelphi Pay Adelphi University's board was never told the details of the pay raises and benefit increases granted to the university's president, a former board chairman testified before a Regents panel. $(B9.$) A 24-year-old male nanny pleaded guilty in Federal District Court in White Plains to sexually abusing an 11-year-old Armonk boy. $(B6.$) Dr. Antonio M. Gotto Jr. was named head of Cornell University Medical College in Manhattan. $(B7.$) NEW JERSEY Charges in Terrorizing Blacks More than a dozen people face charges of carrying out ''something akin to a reign of terror'' against black people in Burlington County, New Jersey officials said. $(B7.$) CONNECTICUT Judge Dismisses Bias Suit A Federal judge has dismissed a former police officer's lawsuit against the town of Avon that claims the Police Department focused on minority motorists in traffic stops. $(B7.$)
